case_name: Rana Umanath Bakshsingh v. Allahabad Bank Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 24, 1958 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in First Execution of Decree Appeal No. 8 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 24, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in First Execution of Decree Appeal No. 8 of 1953.

facts.text: Hearing on April 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate

facts.text: Appellant's father Rana Umanath Bakshsingh was the Talukdar of Khajurgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants father Rana Umanath Bakshsingh was the Talukdar of Khajurgaon. On July 13, 1914, Rana Umanath Bakshsingh executed a simple mortgage

facts.text: On July 13, 1914, Rana Umanath Bakshsingh executed a simple mortgage in favour of Allahabad Bank Limited (respondent) for Rs. 6,00,000 mortgaging proprietary rights in sixty-seven villages.

anchor.surface_text: On July 13, 1914, Rana Umanath Bakshsingh executed a simple mortgage in favour of the Allahabad Bank Limited  hereinafter called the respondent . The mortgage was for a sum of Rs. 6,00,000 and the property mortgaged companysisted of sixty-seven villages.

facts.text: In May 1924, respondent filed suit for recovery of mortgage money by sale of mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: In May 1924, the respondent filed a suit for the recovery of the balance of the unpaid mortgage money by the sale of the mortgaged property.

facts.text: In January 1925, preliminary decree passed for rupees four lacs and odd.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1925 a preliminary decree for the recovery of rupees four lacs and odd was passed, which was made final in July 1926

facts.text: In July 1926, preliminary decree made final directing sale of proprietary rights in sixty-seven villages.

anchor.surface_text: which was made final in July 1926 and directed the sale of the mortgaged property, namely, the proprietary rights of Rana Umanath Bakshsingh in the sixty- seven villages.

facts.text: In 1934, U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act passed; judgment-debtor applied for amendment of decree.

anchor.surface_text: In 1934, the U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act was passed and thereupon an application was made by the judgment-debtor for the amendment of the decree under that Act.

facts.text: On October 19, 1936, decree amended under U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act; pending execution dropped as installments fixed.

anchor.surface_text: On October 19, 1936, the decree was amended under the provisions of that Act and thereafter the pending execution proceedings were dropped as installments had been fixed.

facts.text: On May 25, 1940, respondent applied for execution; objection on limitation rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the respondent applied for execution on-May 25, 1940. Objection was taken to this application on the ground that it was barred by time but this matter was decided against the judgment-debtor

facts.text: On July 1, 1952, U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 (1 of 1951) came into force; zamindari rights of judgment debtor abolished.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1952, the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  1 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Act, came into force. As a companysequence of this enactment, the zamindari rights

facts.text: On September 29, 1952, respondent applied to sell trees and wells in abadi, buildings, bhumidari rights under s.18, and compensation money as substituted security.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, on September 29, 1952, the respondent made an application that as the zamindari rights companyld number be sold, only such rights of the judgment debtor as remained in him after the companying into force of the Act might be sold, namely, the rights in trees and wells in abadi and buildings situate in various villages under sale.

facts.text: Execution court held buildings, trees, wells in abadi liable to sale; entitled to compensation as substituted security; bhumidari rights under s.18 sellable.

anchor.surface_text: The execution companyrt held that the buildings, trees and wells situated in the abadi were liable to be sold in execution of the decree. It further held that the respondent was entitled to companypensation amount granted by the State to the appellant in lieu of zamindari rights as substituted security.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court urging: (i) bhumidari rights under s.18 not sellable; (ii) Sep 20, 1952 application barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the matter in appeal to the High Court, and the two points urged before the High Court were that the bhumidari rights created by s. 18  i  of the Act companyld number be sold in execution of the decree, and  ii  that the application dated September 20, 1952,

facts.text: High Court repelled contentions, held execution can proceed against bhumidari rights and Sep 20, 1952 application within time; dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: was a fresh application for execution and as it was filed over 12 years after the date of the amended decree it was barred by time. The High Court repelled both these companytentions, and held that execution companyld proceed against the bhumidari rights

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained a certificate to appeal to this Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Taluka of Khajurgaon was an estate within the meaning of the Act; vested in State under s.4 notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the Taluka of Khajurgaon was an estate within the meaning of the Act. It may be mentioned that the judgment-debtor had certain sir and khudkashat lands and zamindars grove in the sixty-seven villages companyprised within the Talukdari estate.

facts.text: Wells, trees in abadi, buildings continue to belong to intermediary under s.9; no dispute they are liable to sale.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already pointed out, there was numberdispute before the High Court with respect to wells, and trees in abadi and buildings and it was companyceded there that these were liable to be sold, the only dispute being with respect to bhumidari rights

facts.text: Proprietary rights in sir, khudkashat, grove land vested in State under s.6; bhumidari rights under s.18 are new rights, not mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the proprietary rights in sir and khudkashat land and in grove land have vested in the State and what is companyferred on the intermediary by s. 18 is a new right altogether which he never had and which companyld number therefore have been mortgaged in 1914.

facts.text: Mortgagee can only enforce against compensation money under s.6(h) and s.73 TPA; not against bhumidari rights.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, s. 6  h  read with s. 73 directs that the mortgagee shall proceed in the manner provided in s. 73, namely, follow the companypensation money, and there is numberother way possible for him in view of s. 6 h  with respect to the property which has been acquired under the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal; execution not against bhumidari rights under s.18; appellant gets costs.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and direct that the execution of the decree by the respondent will number be levied against the bhumidari rights created in favour of the appellant under s. 18 of the Act. The appellant will get his companyts of this companyrt and of the High Court.

s. 18 of the Act could also be sold in execution of the decree. arguments.court_reasoning: no need to construe as clear on main Act provisions

holdings.text: The proprietary rights in sir and khudkashat land and in grove land have vested in the State and what is conferred on the intermediary by s. 18 is a new right altogether which he never had and which could not therefore have been mortgaged in 1914.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(a)(i) vests proprietary rights; s.18 deems lands settled as new bhumidari rights post-vesting, unlike s.9 which provides for continuance; contrasted with Rajasthan Act s.23; supported by ss.39,44 on compensation.

holdings.text: s. 6(h) read with s. 73 TPA directs that the mortgagee shall proceed against compensation money only, and there is no other way possible for him with respect to the property acquired under the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(h) prohibits enforcement against intermediary's interest in estate except via s.73 TPA procedure for compulsory acquisition; bhumidari rights not compensation.

holdings.text: Bhumidari rights created under s.18 cannot be sold in execution of the decree as they are new rights not mortgaged and mortgagee limited to compensation money.

anchor.surface_text: s. 18 of the Act could also be sold in execution of the decree. The appellant then took the matter in appeal to the High Court, and the two points urged before the High Court were that the bhumidari rights created by s. 18  i  of the Act could not be sold in execution of the decree,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proprietary rights vested; s.18 new rights; s.6(h) limits remedy to compensation; rejects substituted security argument.

holdings.text: Wells, trees in abadi, and buildings continue to belong to intermediary under s.9 and are liable to be sold if covered by mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: So far as s. 9 is concerned, it is certainly a provision otherwise and it provides as follows- All wells or trees in abadi, and all buildings situate within the limits of an estate, belonging to or held by an intermediary or tenant or other person, whether residing in the village or not, shall continue to belong to or be held by such intermediary, tenant or person, as the case may be,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 expressly provides continuance apart from land which is deemed settled; conceded by parties.

holdings.text: Execution of the decree will not be levied against the bhumidari rights created under s.18; appeal allowed with costs to appellant in this court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and direct that the execution of the decree by the respondent will not be levied against the bhumidari rights created in favour of the appellant under s. 18 of the Act. The appellant will get his costs of this court and of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on above interpretations; procedural relief.

holdings.text: Question of limitation on execution application not considered as conceded unnecessary upon success on main issue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel concession; moot upon resolution of primary issue.

holdings.text: Provisions of U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act s.8(2) do not affect construction of s.6(h) of the Zamindari Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention in this connection was drawn to s. 8 2  of the P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, No. XV of 1953. That Act provides for scaling down of debts of zamindars whose estates have been acquired under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear on main Act provisions; no need to construe.
